rows.title: What is Safeguarding?

title.eng: What is Safeguarding?

introduction.eng:
It is important to know the following guidelines for handling disclosures of abuse, neglect, and violence from participants:

1ï¸âƒ£ **Understand abuse, neglect and exploitation.**

â— **Abuse** refers to a deliberate act of maltreatment that can damage a childâ€™s security, wellbeing, dignity and development. Abuse includes all forms of physical, sexual, psychological and emotional maltreatment. (Save the Children definition)

â— **Violence** against children is defined as forms of physical or mental violence, damage and abuse, neglect or neglectful treatment or maltreatment or exploitation, including sexual abuse. (Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, 1990,
Article 19)

â— **Child exploitation** refers to using the child for economical or sexual benefit, for gratification or profit, often resulting in unjust, cruel and harmful treatment of the child. (Save the Children definition)

2ï¸âƒ£ **Know your organisationâ€™s child safeguarding policies and referral procedures.**

ğŸ“– All organisations should have or develop child rights safeguarding policies and referral procedures, including details on how to respond appropriately when a parent or child discloses abuse. 

ğŸ“ You should have accurate knowledge of all protocols and response plans. These will tell you what to do within your organisation if a parent or child reports abuse (e.g. who to report to, internal resources for supporting the child), as well as how to engage outside resources (e.g. local referral pathways, when to engage with authorities). 

ğŸ”‘ It is your responsibility to act regardless of whether you are responding to disclosures of past and/or present abuse. However, you are not responsible for resolving the situation on your own. It is important that you discuss the situation with your supervisor to agree on what steps to take next.

3ï¸âƒ£ **Ensure parents know that you are someone who can help.**

ğŸŒ·Parents participating in your sessions need to know that they can come to you for help, regardless of when abuse occurred. 

ğŸ‘‚You should make sure that they know that they can trust you and that you will listen and support them without judgement or any further harm.

rows.title: What should I do during the disclosure of abuse, neglect, or exploitation?

title.eng: What should I do during the disclosure of abuse, neglect, or exploitation?

introduction.eng:
**During disclosure:**

ğŸ’š Provide a safe environment in which the participant can share their story.

ğŸ‘‚ Listen carefully to the participant and take notes: what/when/where/who.

â— Determine if the participant is in immediate danger and what help is available.

ğŸ’™ Make sure that the participant feels that you believe him/her.

ğŸŒ· Let them know they have done the right thing by sharing their story with you.

âœ¨ Be supportive and free of judgement in your responses â€“ avoid blaming at all times!

â¡ï¸ Let the participant know that you will share what he/she told you with your supervisor to find a way to support and protect him/her.

ğŸ“ Explain what you are going to do next.

 âœ… Notify @global.supervisor_name.

rows.title: What can I do after a participant discloses abuse, neglect or exploitation?

title.eng: What can I do after a participant discloses abuse, neglect or exploitation?

introduction.eng:
**After disclosure:**

âŒ Avoid engaging with alleged abuser â€“ that may make things worse and make next steps difficult. It could also jeopardise future legal proceedings.

ğŸŒ· You are not alone. Get help from your supervisor to agree on next steps.

rows.title: After Onboarding Session

title.eng: After Onboarding Session

introduction.eng: This chat session should happen on the same day or day after you complete the in-person onboarding session. As the first chat session, it offers a chance for parents to introduce themselves to the group.

section_title_1.eng: Add Ground Rules to the WhatsApp Group Description

section_text_1.eng:
Remember to add the ground rules to the WhatsApp Group Description. â€‹â€‹To add the ground rules to the Group Description, copy the following ground rules or use the ones agreed during the onboarding session: â€œTo make this a safe space for everyone, here are some ground rules:
 
âœ… What is said in the group stays in the group. You need to know that this group is private.
âœ… Accept each other. Everyone is different and has different experiences.
âœ… Share only what you feel comfortable sharing.
âœ… Feel free to ask questions!
âœ… Respect privacy of personal pictures and videos that are sent to the chat group. 
âœ… I am only here as an observer. I will not respond to questions about your parenting habits in this group or personally. However, if there is a message that will benefit the entire group, then I will share a general message here.â€

Open the WhatsApp group chat. Tap the group name. Tap the existing description, or tap Add Group Description. 
Paste the ground rules. Tap Save.

message_title_1.eng: Message 1: Introduction

message_text_1.eng:
ğŸ˜ƒ Hi there! Welcome to our Naungan Kasih WhatsApp Group! 

Today we are introducing ourselves and our goals for the programme! â­ 

My name is [INSERT NAME] and my goal is to learn more about how to help my child go to bed by 8 every night.â°ğŸŒ™ 

Please share your name and your goal for Naungan Kasih using text or audio message.

message_guidance_1.eng:
Remember to fill in your name where it says [INSERT NAME] before sending your message. 

Allow some time for parents to share. Try to praise each response.
For example, you can say â€œThanks for the response, [Insert Name]!â€ or â€œGreat goal, [Insert Name]â€! You can also use simple emojis like ğŸ‘or ğŸ™‚

message_text_2.eng:
Every week, we will catch up at [INSERT TIME] on [INSERT DAY] to chat about our Naungan Kasih journey. 

ğŸ‘‹Please join to share how things are going, any challenges you experience, or just say hi! ğŸ˜Š

â°Does this time and day work for everyone?

message_guidance_2.eng: Add the time and day of the week before sending the message.

message_text_3.eng:
ğŸ˜ƒThank you so much for being part of our WhatsApp chat group! 

As your home practice, try to spend at least 5 minutes of One-on-One Time with your child each day. 

We can share about how it goes during our next chat session. 

ğŸ‘‹See you next week.

message_text_4.eng: During the programme, you may be asked to complete a child development assessment. The aim of this assessment is to alert parents on general activities that are age-appropriate for your child. Based on the answers you provide, this screening tool may provide resources to follow up with a healthcare provider or provide resources for government services. If you receive this message, please don't panic. This is not a diagnostic tool and it does not mean that your child has a disability. These recommendations are provided for the benefit of the child if help is needed to promote their healthy growth. Thank you.

rows.title: Week 1: One-on-One Time

title.eng: Week 1: One-on-One Time

introduction.eng:
This session allows parents to discuss their home activity of spending at least 5 minutes of one-on-one time. 
Remember, the key building blocks for One-on-One time are Day, Play, and Stay:

**DAY** Try to do it every day
Spend 5 minutes (or more!) One-on-One time with your child each day.

**PLAY** Let them choose the activity
Tell your child that you would like to spend some time with them and that they can choose what to do or talk about. They might think this is weird at first but will come to enjoy this time with you!

**STAY** Focus on your child 
Switch off TV and put aside phones. Look at your child or teen. Nod or say â€œI seeâ€ to show you are really paying attention. Accept what they say without judging them.

The home activity is for parents to spend at least 5 minutes of one-on-one time with their child each day.

message_title_1.eng: Message 1: Reminder

message_text_1.eng: ğŸ’šHello everyone! Our next chat session will be later today at [INSERT TIME]. Chat soon!

message_guidance_1.eng: Send this message in the morning on the day of the chat session. Insert the time for the chat before sending the message.

message_text_2.eng:
Hi everyone! ğŸ˜ƒ 

Our second chat session will start now.. ğŸŒ±How is everybody doing? Please feel free to share how you are feeling through messages or emojis. â­

message_guidance_2.eng: Allow time for parents to share how they are feeling. You should also share how you are feeling. For example, â€œI am happy to be part of the chat today.

message_text_3.eng:
ğŸŒ·Thank you for sharing! Just showing up today shows that you care! 

Our home activity for the week was spending 5 minutes of One-on-One Time with your child each day. 

How did it go for you? â­

message_guidance_3.eng: Respond to the parents with an appropriate emoji or with an appropriate response from the common challenges.

message_text_4.eng:
Thanks for sharing so many wonderful responses! ğŸ‰ 

We are all learning here so please remember that the most important thing is that you give it your best. 

It is what you do at home with your child that makes a difference! ğŸ˜ƒ

rows.title: Week 4: Final Chat Session

title.eng: Week 4: Final Chat Session

introduction.eng:
This week is your final chat session with the group. It can be an emotional time for parentsâ€¦and for you. You should congratulate yourself for taking the parents through the Naungan Kasih journey and celebrate with them the positive changes in their lives and for their children. 

During this chat session, you will share the names of the two group admin to keep the WhatsApp Support Group ongoing, and handover the WhatsApp group administration rights to them. 

Remember, the WhatsApp groups are designed to support parent engagement in the ParentText chatbot. 

Before this chat session, you should have selected the two parents to lead the group. Enter the name of the parents after sharing the Group Message 3. If no one volunteered, see FAQ below. 

For next steps after selecting the group admin, see â€œHanding over to Group Adminâ€ on the homepage. 

You can choose to stay or leave the WhatsApp Group after the program ends.

message_title_1.eng: Message 1: Reminder

message_text_1.eng: Hello! Our last chat session will be later today at [INSERT TIME]. See you then! ğŸ‘‹

message_guidance_1.eng: Send this message in the morning on the day of the chat session. Insert the time for the chat before sending the message.

message_text_2.eng:
ğŸ‘‹Hi everyone, welcome to the final chat session together on Naungan Kasih. 

âœ¨ Take a moment to think back to the beginning of the programme. How have you and your child changed?

message_guidance_2.eng: Allow parents to share about the changes that they have experienced during the programme. You can give brief words of encouragement like â€œWonderful!â€ or â€œI am happy to hear that!â€ or even share celebration emojis like ğŸ‰or â­.

message_text_3.eng: Thank you for sharing your experiences. It is wonderful to see how much you have changed over the course of the programme. Remember that your parenting journey continues! ğŸ’š

message_text_4.eng: Although this is my last chat session with you, you are in good hands with your new chat group admin: [INSERT NAMES OF MODERATORS] ğŸ’™

message_text_5.eng:
I will now be exiting this WhatsApp Group. ğŸ‘‹

You are the best parents to your children *You can still complete your final ParentText Goals and Skills if you have not done so yet*. ğŸŒ±

We all face difficult situations sometimes, and these final parts of ParentText will help you and your child to get through them well. 

Youâ€™ve got this! â­You are doing a wonderful job as a parent. It has been a pleasure to be on this journey with you!

title.eng: A parent needs support accessing ParentText and I'm not sure how to answer their question.

introduction.eng: Reach out for support to @global.supervisor_name.

rows.introduction: Reach out for support to @global.supervisor_name.

rows.title: A parent cannot commit to the ground rules.

title.eng: A parent cannot commit to the ground rules.

introduction.eng:
Ground rules make your WhatsApp Support Group a safe space for everyone. 

If someone forgets the ground rules, send the message below to gently remind them of their importance. 

If necessary, share a group reminder about the importance of maintaining a positive and respectful space. 

If, despite reminders, the parent continues not to follow the rules, notify your supervisor. 

You can remove the parent from the group as the last option, done only when you feel it is necessary. For example, if a member repeatedly shares unrelated content, uses inappropriate language or is disrespectful to another member. 

If you do remove someone from the group, it should be handled with sensitivity and respect. Make sure you talk privately with the parent, remind the group about ground rules, and notify your supervisor.

message_title_1.eng: Send this reminder message to the group

message_text_1.eng:
Hello â­

ğŸ‘€ I'd like to take a moment to remind everyone about the importance of our group's ground rules. 

ğŸ’šThey're here to ensure that all of us feel comfortable sharing and maintain a positive environment. 

ğŸŒ±It's all about making this group a great place for everyone.

â—Please keep in mind that if the ground rules aren't consistently followed, we might need to consider removing members from the WhatsApp group for the well-being of all.

See you in the next chat session.

message_title_2.eng: Send this reminder message to the parent who broke the ground rule

message_text_2.eng:
Hello â­

ğŸ‘€ Creating a positive environment in our WhatsApp group is important, and that relies on everyone following the ground rules.

ğŸŒ± I believe in the strength of our community. 

However, if difficulties continue, I may have to consider removing you from the group. 

Let's work together to maintain a respectful and supportive atmosphere. 

See you in the next chat session.

message_title_3.eng: Send this message to the parent after removing them from the WhatsApp Group

message_text_3.eng:
Hello â­

ğŸ‘€ I have noticed despite reminders, the ground rules aren't being followed.

ğŸ’šYou can continue learning from ParentText, but unfortunately I have removed you from the WhatsApp group to maintain a positive environment for everyone.

message_guidance_3.eng:
Notify your supervisor once you remove them. 
You can block the parent if they continue to reach out to you.

message_title_4.eng: Send this message to the group after removing the parent who broke the ground rule

message_text_4.eng:
Hello Everyone â­,

ğŸ‘€ We want our group to be positive for everyone, and that means following the rules.

ğŸ’š Unfortunately, someone had to be removed because they weren't following the rules despite reminders.

Let's keep things respectful and supportive.See you in the next chat session!

rows.title: What if no one participates?

title.eng: What if no one participates?

introduction.eng:
Engaging parents in the group chat can sometimes be hard. Some parents may need a nudge to share their experiences or they might be busy with their schedules.

rows.title: Overview of the Naungan Kasih Programme

title.eng: Overview of the Naungan Kasih Programme

introduction.eng:
Welcome to the Naungan Kasih Positive Parenting Programme! 

Thank you for your commitment and dedication to supporting children and families in your community. 
You are a shining star!

section_text_1.eng:
This guide is for YOU!! 
A comprehensive guide to help you deliver Naungan Kasih to families around you. 
Steps on how to introduce caregivers to the programme, and support them
Specific information on the programmeâ€™s content.

section_text_2.eng:
It is important to follow this manual as closely as possible. However, manuals are only a guide to support you after what you have learned in the training workshop. 
What you deliver â€“ the content of the manual â€“ is only 20% of the programme. The rest 80%? Itâ€™s all about HOW you facilitate the programme and behave towards the parents.

section_text_3.eng: The core skills of a good facilitator are a mirror for parents to learn how to bring about the change we want to see in parents and the community. These include understanding stages of child development, praising and encouraging parents, using active listening skills, being consistent and compassionate, exploring problems, and finding solutions together.

section_text_4.eng:
Just as we say to the parents, â€œIt is what you do at home that makes the difference,â€ the same thing applies to you: â€œIt is how you interact with the parents in your group that makes the difference.â€ 

If you take the time to deliver a session before it begins, you will be more confident. If there is anything that you cannot remember or feel unsure of, contact another facilitator to practise with. 

Access the Facilitator Guide for your group by clicking on the icon above.

rows.title: How to Conduct Weekly WhatsApp Group Sessions

title.eng: How to Conduct Weekly WhatsApp Group Sessions

introduction.eng:
The Naungan Kasih programme includes WhatsApp Groups with parents with pre-scripted messages that you share each week from FaciNK. 

The aim of this group is to provide parents with extra support during their Naungan Kasih journey.

section_text_1.eng:
**Make sure you have done the following before the onboarding session starts:** 

- Save the names and WhatsApp numbers of the parents assigned to you on your phone (if available), so you can easily confirm details during the onboarding session. 

- Create your WhatsApp group (with temporary group name, icon, description). The name of each WhatsApp group has the same structure:
â€œNaungan Kasihâ€
Your group (B or D) 
A name selected by the group 

When you create your temporary group name, you will use the first 2 parts: "Naungan Kasihâ€ + your group. 

For example, if you have a WhatsApp group for group B, your temporary group name will be â€œNaungan Kasih_GroupBâ€. 

You can keep your temporary group name or you can add a name to the temporary group name. For example, â€œNaungan Kasih_GroupA_HappyFamiliesâ€.

section_text_2.eng:
**Before conducting weekly sessions, make sure you:** 

Create a WhatsApp Group during the onboarding session. 
Identify the ground rules for the WhatsApp Group

**Structure for the weekly chat session**: Week 0 (immediately after the onboarding session): Welcome, introductions, and reminder of home practice. Week 1: One-on-one time: Checking in on the home activity of spending 5 minutes of one-on-one time with their child. 

Week 2: Check-in: Connecting with parents on their progress with ParentText. 

Week 3: Check-in: Connecting with parents on their progress with ParentText, and identifying group admin to hand over the group after Week 4. 

Week 4: Final Chat Sessions: Sharing new group admin details, and closing.

**When to send the messages** 

You and your group will decide a time to chat during the onboarding session. Each chat session has a reminder message (Message 1) that you should send a few hours before the chat session. 

Send the remaining messages during the scheduled chat time.

section_title_3.eng: Share the messages in weekly session

section_text_3.eng:
Look for the "Weekly Sessions" section on FaciNK homepage

Find the specific week you want to share and click on it.

Once you're on the content for that week, locate the "Share" icon. It should look like an arrow pointing upward or a box with an arrow, and it's used to share content. Click on the "Share" icon.

In the menu that appears, select "WhatsApp" as your sharing option.

Choose your Naungan Kasih Support Group from the list. 

Before you hit the "Send" button, make sure to add or change any necessary information like your name. 

Finally, click the "Send" button to share the content with your Naungan Kasih Support Group.

section_title_4.eng: Get Help with WhatsApp Support Group

section_text_4.eng:
If you require help while moderating your WhatsApp Support Group, the weekly sessions provide a list of FAQ and potential solutions.

If you need support responding to a challenge shared by the parent during your weekly chat session, see â€œCommon Challengesâ€ on the homepage. 

Follow the same instructions as Sharing Weekly Messages to share the solutions to the challenges. 

If you encounter a challenge not covered in the weekly session, kindly contact your supervisor for further guidance.

rows.title: How to hand over to Group Admin

title.eng: How to hand over to Group Admin

introduction.eng:
Once 2 volunteers to be group admin are selected, schedule a WhatsApp call with the them.

When youâ€™re done with the call, you can send the guidelines as messages to remind them what you discussed.

section_title_1.eng: What to cover in the WhatsApp Call?

section_text_1.eng:
Thank the parent for volunteering to lead the WhatsApp group.  

While engaging with other parents in the group, keep the following in mind:
ğŸ”µGreet parents when engaging with them.
ğŸ”µRespect what participants share and be aware of different ages, genders, values and circumstances.
ğŸ”µEncourage parents to share and respond to each other - and praise them for it.
ğŸ”µRemind parents of ground rules when needed.
ğŸ”µModel the behaviour you want to see among the parents.

If the parent needs any prompts for discussion, share the following: 

Let us celebrate our successes! What was something positive you experienced when you tried one of the ParentText skills with your child?

Trying out new skills can be hard at first. What was something difficult that you experienced when you tried a ParentText skill with your child at home?
Remind the parent that they are not obligated to respond to messages all times. Participants may send messages at any time during the week. To keep your workload manageable, you can respond to messages once or twice a day, depending on your schedule. 

Ask them if they have any questions. 

Remind the parent that unfortunately, you will no longer be able to participate in the WhatsApp group.

message_title_1.eng: Send this message after your WhatsApp Call

message_text_1.eng:

ğŸ‘‹Greet parents when engaging with them.

ğŸ’›Respect what participants share and be aware of different ages, genders, values and circumstances.

ğŸ”‘Model the behaviour you want to see among the parents.

message_title_2.eng: When should the group admin respond to messages?

message_text_2.eng:

â°Participants may send messages at any time during the week. To keep your workload manageable, you can respond to messages once or twice a day, depending on your schedule.

ğŸ…Encourage parents to share and respond to each other - and praise them for it.

ğŸ””Remind parents of ground rules when needed.

ğŸ”‘Model the behaviour you want to see among the parents.
rows.message_title_2: When should the group admin respond to messages?
rows.message_text_2:
*When should you respond to messages?*

â°Participants may send messages at any time during the week. To keep your workload manageable, you can respond to messages once or twice a day, depending on your schedule. 

ğŸ‘You can also respond to messages with a relevant emoji or short response when you can.
rows.message_guidance_2: Send this message to the group admin volunteers.

The FaciNK also makes reporting on the delivery of Naungan Kasih much easier than paper forms.

After adding each parentâ€™s name to the App, you will be able to report on their participation during the in-person session.

Select your state from the dropdown menu

rows.title: Spending one-on-one time

title.eng: Spending one-on-one time

introduction.eng:
Parenting can be challenging and many obstacles can get in the way.

Remember, your job isn't to solve their problems, but enable a conversation between parents to support one another. ğŸ”„

Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for spending one-on-one time that we have encountered previously when delivering the programme. You can share the following messages as responses during your weekly chat when parents share challenges with this topic.

message_title_1.eng: I didnâ€™t have enough time to spend one-on-one time.

message_text_1.eng: Thank you for sharing. It can be hard to find time, especially when you have work, chores, and other responsibilities to do. ğŸ˜” You could try finding a chore to do together.

message_title_2.eng: My child did not want to spend time with me.

message_text_2.eng: Thank you for sharing. It feels sad when your child doesn't want to spend time with you. ğŸ˜” Try suggesting a fun activity to do together.

message_title_3.eng: All my child wanted to do was watch T.V. or play with a gadget.

message_text_3.eng:
It can be tough when your child seems focused on watching TV or playing with a gadget all the time. ğŸ˜Ÿ 

To connect with them and understand their interests, try asking them to show you something cool on the gadget. 

It's a simple way to engage with their world and spend time together. ğŸ“º

message_title_4.eng: My child did not want one-on-one time to end.

message_text_4.eng:
I understand it can be tough when your child does not want one-on-one time to end. ğŸ˜£To make things smoother, try being clear about how much time you have together and give a gentle warning when the time is about to end. â°

To help you with managing your childâ€™s behaviour, consider making â€œSupport My Childâ€™s Positive Behaviourâ€ as your next parenting goal once you finish your current goal.

message_title_5.eng: My child wanted to do activities that I could not do.

message_text_5.eng:
I can imagine it's challenging when your child wants to do activities that you find difficult. ğŸ˜”

 A simple solution is to ask your child if you can join in by watching. 

This way, you're still involved and supportive, even if you can't participate directly. ğŸ¤

rows.title: Praising your child

title.eng: Praising your child

introduction.eng:
It is normal for parents to feel uncomfortable or have challenges when praising their children. They may at first think that praise will either inflate their children or is not part of their culture. 

It is important to remember that there are many different ways to praise children. Naungan Kasih focuses mainly on praise as a method to reinforce positive behaviour. We praise the behaviour more than just the child!

Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for praising your child. 
You can share the following messages as responses during your weekly chat when parents share challenges with this topic.

message_title_1.eng: I forgot to praise my child.

message_text_1.eng:
ğŸ’šIt can be difficult to juggle all the different things we need to do. 

ğŸŒ±Next time you spend one-on-one time, try and think of one thing you can praise them for. 

â˜€ï¸You can even say, â€œThank you for
spending time with me!â€

message_title_2.eng: I felt embarrassed or weird when praising my child.

message_text_2.eng:
â­Itâ€™s normal to feel uneasy about doing new things.

ğŸŒ·This is especially true of praise when we are not used to hearing it ourselves. 

ğŸ‘€But it will get easier with practice,I promise!

message_title_3.eng: I canâ€™t think of anything to praise my child.

message_text_3.eng:
ğŸ””Start small! You donâ€™t have to select anything big to praise. 

ğŸ’¡Find a simple behaviour that your child does that you are happy about and tell them. Even something that they already do. 

â™¥ï¸ It will make a difference!

rows.title: Talking about feelings

title.eng: Talking about feelings

introduction.eng:
It is completely normal for parents to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. Parents may be trying to recognise their emotions and communicate about them for the first time here.

Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for talking about feelings. 
You can share the following messages as responses during your weekly chat when parents share challenges with this topic.

message_title_1.eng: My child did not want to share their emotions.

message_text_1.eng:
ğŸ’šI understand that sharing feelings is challenging when itâ€™s new. 

ğŸŒ±Be patient and keep providing them with the opportunity to start sharing. 

â˜€ï¸Be a model for your children by sharing your own feelings.

message_title_2.eng: I felt uncomfortable talking about my own feelings

message_text_2.eng:
â­It's okay to feel uncomfortable talking about your own feelings. 

ğŸ‘€A simple way to start is by using 'I feel...' 

ğŸŒ·For example, you could say, "I feel happy when we spend time together." Starting small like this can make it easier.

message_title_3.eng: Others in the household donâ€™t think itâ€™s a good idea to talk about emotions.

message_text_3.eng:
ğŸ””You can try talking to them about why it might be a good idea. 

ğŸ’¡Encourage them to try it first. Sometimes, just giving it a try can help everyone understand each other better.

message_title_4.eng: Others in the household donâ€™t think itâ€™s a good idea to talk about negative emotions.

message_text_4.eng:
ğŸ””Maybe you can have a chat with them about why it could be a good idea. 

ğŸ’¡Encourage them to give it a try! Talking openly about feelings can help everyone understand each other better.

message_title_5.eng: I donâ€™t know how to name some of the feelings I am experiencing.

message_text_5.eng:
âœ¨Naming feelings can be tough. 

ğŸ”„Try combining words you know, like happy or sad, and think about where you feel it in your body. 

ğŸ”´For example, if your chest feels tight, it might be stress. 

ğŸ”¶It's okay not to have all the words â€“ describe it the best you can.

rows.title: Supporting childâ€™s development

title.eng: Supporting childâ€™s development

introduction.eng:
Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for supporting parents to help their children develop in a healthy way. 
You can share the following messages as responses during your weekly chat when parents share challenges with this topic.

message_title_1.eng: I donâ€™t have time to interact with my child.

message_text_1.eng:
It is okay to feel that way. But there are many small ways to spend time with your child!

â° You can interact with your child while doing something else. Like, try asking your child to describe the colours and objects they see around them while you are walking together or while commuting on a bus.

ğŸ˜ƒ Your child will appreciate the attention you are giving, even for a short while.

message_title_2.eng: My child is not interested in spending time with me.

message_text_2.eng:
ğŸ˜£ You may be hurt because your child does not want to spend time with you.

â° Sometimes, your child just needs time to engage with you. It helps to remain calm, patient, and kind while you try to connect with your child.

ğŸŒ± As children grow, they may want independence from you. Thatâ€™s normal! You can support them to find friends based on their interests.

message_title_3.eng: My child keeps getting hurt from exploring or making new friends.

message_text_3.eng:
ğŸ§¸ It must be hard to see your child getting injured or feeling sad. 

ğŸŒ·Children learn and grow from making mistakes. It is an important part of child development. They will be safe as long as you are aware of their activities and you can prevent anything dangerous.

â­ Build your childâ€™s confidence about their abilities, values, and appearance so that they are comfortable trying new things.

ğŸ¨ Encourage them to safely try out fun activities with other kids or adults. Praise them when they do it well!

ğŸ’š Let your child know that you trust them to be safe and follow the rules that you have set.

message_title_4.eng: My children will think I am not strong if I share my own mistakes.

message_text_4.eng:
ğŸ’šItâ€™s completely normal to feel worried about how your children might see you if you share your mistakes. 

ğŸ†Sharing your mistakes shows your child how you have learned and grown from your mistake, and they can do the same. 

â­It shows your children how you are stronger after learning your mistakes.

message_title_5.eng: I donâ€™t understand the GROW development assessment.

message_text_5.eng:
I understand that the GROW development assessment might be confusing at first. 

The GROW assessment helps parents, like you, track how their child is growing. 

It shows where they're doing well and where they might need extra help. 

Remember, the questions in ParentText about your child's development are not for diagnosing issues. If you're worried, it's best to consult a professional.

rows.title: Supporting children's reading and maths learning

title.eng: Supporting children's reading and maths learning

introduction.eng:
Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for supporting parents to help their childrenâ€™s learning in reading and maths. 
You can share the following messages as responses during your weekly chat when parents share challenges with this topic.

message_title_1.eng: I did not find time to help my child learn.

message_text_1.eng:
It can be difficult to find time to help your child learn, but there are two important things to remember:

1ï¸âƒ£ Your child can learn a lot just by joining in activities you do in your normal routine. Going shopping for food, sorting clothes, and cooking are great opportunities to talk to your child and for them to learn. 
ğŸ… Describe what you are doing and ask questions. If you can, play counting games, and point out numbers, shapes and letters that you see. For example, square signs and round signs, and numbers and letters on labels. ğŸ”· ğŸ”µ

2ï¸âƒ£ You can help your child learn by spending just a short amount of time specifically on a learning activity. For example, can you find 5 minutes in the evening to look at pictures together or read a childrenâ€™s book? ğŸ“–

message_text_2.eng:

ğŸ‘€ You can also use anything that has pictures to interact with your child - magazines, newspapers, and even signs on the road.

message_title_3.eng: My child does not want to learn.

message_text_3.eng:

rows.title: Helping your child give structure

title.eng: Helping your child give structure

introduction.eng:
Here are some common challenges and possible solutions that parents may experience when giving their children structure. 
You can share the following messages as responses during your weekly chat when parents share challenges with this topic.

message_title_1.eng: My child did not follow instructions even when I followed the tips.

message_text_1.eng: ğŸ’™I understand it can be challenging when your child doesn't follow instructions. Remember, children need time to learn these skills. Be patient with the process, and don't hesitate to try again.ğŸŒ±

message_title_2.eng:
I gave a negative instead of a positive
instruction.

message_text_2.eng:
ğŸ’›It takes time to get used to giving positive
instructions â€“ but itâ€™s worth trying again! Try
thinking about the behaviour you would like to see your child to more often and think of positive ways to give that instruction.ğŸŒ·

message_title_3.eng:
My child did not hear me or ignored
me.

message_text_3.eng:
â­It can be tough when your child doesn't listen. 

ğŸ‘€Try getting their attention by looking at them or gently touching their shoulder before telling them something. That might help them hear you better.

message_title_4.eng:
My child had difficulty following my
instructions.

message_text_4.eng:
It's hard when your child struggles to follow what you ask. 

1ï¸âƒ£Try giving just one instruction at a time, something they can easily do. And remember to give them enough time to do it. This can make following instructions easier for them.

message_title_5.eng: We were not able to stick to the rule or routine

message_text_5.eng: Try making a rule or routine that's easy to follow, like cleaning up toys after playing. This way, it's simpler for everyone to keep up with it.

rows.title: Setting household rules and routines

title.eng: Setting household rules and routines

introduction.eng:
Establishing regular household rules and routines can be difficult for parents at first. 

It is important that they focus on positive behaviours like â€œPlay inside the gardenâ€ instead of â€œDonâ€™t play in the street.â€ This may not feel natural at first for parents so they will need some encouragement and support.

Parents may also not feel comfortable involving their children in establishing a rule or routine. You can remind them that this will make it more likely that their child will follow the rule and will also help their child learn responsibilities.

Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for setting household rules and routines. 
You can share the following messages as responses during your weekly chat when parents share challenges with this topic.

message_title_1.eng: My child struggled to go along with the bedtime routine.

message_text_1.eng: It takes time for children to learn new routines and change their behaviour. Be patient and keep the bedtime routine consistent.

message_title_2.eng: My child and I could not agree on a rule.

message_text_2.eng:
Think about whether the rule is reasonable. Can your child do it? 

It helps when making rules as a family to think about your child, how old they are
and what really matters to them.

message_title_3.eng: My child felt it was unfair that I donâ€™t have to follow the rule we set.

message_text_3.eng:
We should always remember that children learn best from us. The more we follow the rules, the more they will follow the rules too. 

You can adjust the rule to make sure that it is realistic for everyone to follow it, considering their and your responsibilities (for example school or work activities).

message_title_4.eng: Parent should be the one setting the rule, not the child.

message_text_4.eng:
When we establish rules together with our
children, that helps the family to understand each other better.

 The rules will be more realistic and children will be more willing and able to follow the rules.

message_title_5.eng: We made the rule but my child does not follow it.

message_text_5.eng:
I get that it's challenging when your child isn't following the rule you set. ğŸ˜”

Think about your rule â€“ is it fair and realistic? What can your child actually do? Adjust the rule, if necessary. 

Praise your child when they do follow the rule.

rows.title: Giving consequences

title.eng: Giving consequences

introduction.eng:
Giving appropriate and fair consequences when their children misbehave is an important skill for parents to learn. It will help avoid more harmful discipline practices.

Consequences are most effective when used to support following instructions or household rules and routines that have already been discussed with children.

Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for giving consequences.
You can share the following messages as responses during your weekly chat when parents share challenges with this topic.

message_title_1.eng: I am too angry to find anything positive to say to my child after they have misbehaved.

message_text_1.eng: Take a deep breath, take some space, and then pick something very small and concrete that you wish your child could do more of that you can praise in your child.

message_title_2.eng: My child doesnâ€™t seem to have changed their behaviour despite the consequence I put in place.

message_text_2.eng: It takes time for anyoneâ€™s behaviour to change. Remember to consistently apply the consequence â€“ you need to do it every time â€“ and to put it into place immediately.

message_title_3.eng: My child is misbehaving all the time.

message_text_3.eng: You may need to spend more One-on-One Time with your child and give more positive attention to them when they are behaving well. This takes time so be patient!

rows.title: Supporting positive child behaviour

title.eng: Supporting positive child behaviour

introduction.eng:
Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for supporting positive child behaviour. 
You can share the following messages as responses during your weekly chat when parents share challenges with this topic.

message_title_1.eng: Other members of the family do not agree about using ignore for tantrums or other demanding behaviours.

message_text_1.eng:
ğŸš©Sometimes others will not agree with us or have other methods of parenting. 

ğŸ’¡It might be helpful to explain to other family members how to use ignore and why it might help reduce your childrenâ€™s demanding behaviours. 

âœ¨You can only control your behaviour so remember that these changes start with you and with time others might see that they really work!

message_title_2.eng: I canâ€™t ignore my childâ€™s behaviour because they are hitting/biting/pushing.

message_text_2.eng:
ğŸ”‘Ignore only works for negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like whining, pestering, and tantrums.

Using consequences is more effective for
aggressive behaviours like hitting. Your child might need a break from an activity to cool down if they are being aggressive. 

â¸ You can teach them to Take a Pause!

message_title_3.eng: I canâ€™t ignore my childâ€™s behaviour because I am afraid they will hurt themselves.

message_text_3.eng:
â—It is important to keep your child safe. If they get out of control during a tantrum, you might need to take them to a place where they cannot hurt themselves. 

You also might need to gently but firmly hold your child while continuing to ignore them verbally. 

Remember that we are ignoring the behaviour but not the child!

message_title_4.eng: Ignoring the behaviour just seems to make it worse!

message_text_4.eng:
ğŸ‘€It is completely natural for your child to test you. They have learned that by increasing their demanding behaviour they might get what they want. 

ğŸ’šBe patient and continue to practise ignoring. Eventually, your child will learn that this behaviour does not work.

message_title_5.eng: I am having to ignore my childâ€™s behaviour a lot of the time. It just does not work!

message_text_5.eng:
This may be either because 1ï¸âƒ£ you are not being consistent with ignoring, 2ï¸âƒ£ the behaviour is not one that you can ignore, or 3ï¸âƒ£ your child needs more positive attention at other times. 

Remember to spend plenty of One-on-One Time with your children.

rows.title: Keeping the child safe and healthy

title.eng: Keeping the child safe and healthy

introduction.eng:
Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for keeping children safe and healthy. 
You can share the following messages as responses during your weekly chat when parents share challenges with this topic.

message_title_1.eng: My child is always on a gadget, even when I am working or doing house chores.

message_text_1.eng:
ğŸ“º It must be exhausting to always tell your child to turn off or put away the gadgets.

ğŸ“ You can set rules with your child. Tell them that they cannot be on gadgets when you are busy. Your busy time is your childâ€™s quiet play time with toys or reading time with books.

ğŸŒ· Tell your child that sharing what they watch on T.V. or what they do on gadgets is a rule. 

ğŸ‘‚ Be patient and kind while listening to them. Manage your anger if you find that they did something wrong online. Take a deep breath.

ğŸ’› Praise your child when they follow the rules!

message_title_2.eng: My child is refusing to eat vegetables and fruits, especially when they are out of the house.

message_text_2.eng:
ğŸ… It is common for children to refuse vegetables and fruits, especially when tastier but less healthy food options are available all around us.

ğŸŒ± You could encourage your child to eat slightly sweeter fruits and vegetables for a start, such as mango childs and sweet potatoes. You can gradually introduce other vegetables and fruits.

ğŸˆ Praise you child even when they take one mouthful of vegetables or fruits!

message_title_3.eng: I am worried because my child returns home late at night after playing.

message_text_3.eng:
ğŸš©I understand it can be unsafe when your child comes home late after playing outside.

â°Consider establishing a household rule for when your child should come home. Work together with your child to set fair consequences if they don't follow the rule.

ğŸ’šTo support you in setting rules with your child, think about making "Give My Child Structure" your next parenting goal once you complete your current one.

message_title_4.eng: My child told me that school or the house of someone I trust is an unsafe place. ğŸš© I was shocked and did not know what to do!

message_text_4.eng:
ğŸ˜” It is shocking to learn that people who we trust may cause discomfort to our children.

ğŸ‘‚ Listen to your child if they want to talk about why it seems dangerous or uncomfortable. Trust what they say - they will not say such things for no reason!

ğŸ””Talk with someone and get support. Type {HELP} if you need more assistance.

ğŸ’™ Remember to take a pause when you are stressed.

message_title_5.eng: I am shy to talk to my young child about bodies and safe touch.

message_text_5.eng:
ğŸ’™ It is slightly uncomfortable to talk to our children about male and female body parts.

ğŸ’¡But it helps to keep our children safe. Your child will know that they can come to you about any questions related to the body.

ğŸ’š While it may be uncomfortable to talk about some body parts, especially private parts, your child will know how to talk about it if anything happens.

ğŸ”‘ Answer any questions from your child honestly. You can do this to keep our children safe!ğŸŒ·
